issues.title: class properties disappear if assigned a var that has no value assigned
php json_decode ($ str, 1) isset is invalid after passing to zephir
issues.body:
post data: ``` rows:[{"item_id":1,"parent_id":null,"depth":1,"left":1,"right":10}, {"id":"59818f067e52392064000042","parent_id":1,"depth":1,"left":2,"right":3}, {"id":"59818f607e52392064000047","parent_id":1,"depth":1,"left":4,"right":5}, {"id":"59a26e607e52391c180035d2","parent_id":1,"depth":1,"left":6,"right":9}, {"id":"59818f867e523921ec00733c","parent_id":"59a26e607e52391c180035d2","depth":2,"left":7,"right":8}] ``` php code ```php $rows=$this->request->getPost('rows'); $rows=json_decode($rows,true); var_export(rows); \XqKeji\Test::change($rows); ``` output data: ```php array ( 0 => array ( 'item_id' => 1, 'parent_id' => NULL, 'depth' => 1, 'left' => 1, 'right' => 10, ), 1 => array ( 'id' => '59818f067e52392064000042', 'parent_id' => 1, 'depth' => 1, 'left' => 2, 'right' => 3, ), 2 => array ( 'id' => '59818f607e52392064000047', 'parent_id' => 1, 'depth' => 1, 'left' => 4, 'right' => 5, ), 3 => array ( 'id' => '59a26e607e52391c180035d2', 'parent_id' => 1, 'depth' => 1, 'left' => 6, 'right' => 9, ), 4 => array ( 'id' => '59818f867e523921ec00733c', 'parent_id' => '59a26e607e52391c180035d2', 'depth' => 2, 'left' => 7, 'right' => 8, ), ) ```

zephir code

```zep namespace XqKeji; class Test { public static function change(array data=[]) { var row; for row in data { var_export(row); if isset row["parent_id"] { echo "exits parent_id"; } } } } ```

output data:

```php array ( 'item_id' => 1, 'parent_id' => NULL, 'depth' => 1, 'left' => 1, 'right' => 10, ) array ( 'id' => '59818f067e52392064000042', 'parent_id' => 1, 'depth' => 1, 'left' => 2, 'right' => 3, ) array ( 'id' => '59818f607e52392064000047', 'parent_id' => 1, 'depth' => 1, 'left' => 4, 'right' => 5, ) array ( 'id' => '59a26e607e52391c180035d2', 'parent_id' => 1, 'depth' => 1, 'left' => 6, 'right' => 9, ) array ( 'id' => '59818f867e523921ec00733c', 'parent_id' => '59a26e607e52391c180035d2', 'depth' => 2, 'left' => 7, 'right' => 8, ) ```

change the zephir code

```zep namespace XqKeji; class Test { public static function change(array data=[]) { var row; for row in data { let row = json_decode(json_encode(row),1); var_export(row); if isset row["parent_id"] { echo "exits parent_id"; } } } } ``` ```php array ( 'item_id' => 1, 'parent_id' => NULL, 'depth' => 1, 'left' => 1, 'right' => 10, )exits parent_id array ( 'id' => '59818f067e52392064000042', 'parent_id' => 1, 'depth' => 1, 'left' => 2, 'right' => 3, )exits parent_id array ( 'id' => '59818f607e52392064000047', 'parent_id' => 1, 'depth' => 1, 'left' => 4, 'right' => 5, )exits parent_id array ( 'id' => '59a26e607e52391c180035d2', 'parent_id' => 1, 'depth' => 1, 'left' => 6, 'right' => 9, )exits parent_id array ( 'id' => '59818f867e523921ec00733c', 'parent_id' => '59a26e607e52391c180035d2', 'depth' => 2, 'left' => 7, 'right' => 8, )exits parent_id ``` I use `json_encode` and `json_decode` the test is valid. php7.0.15 nts zephir 0.10.6 win 10

issues.title: [BUG] Assignment to protected static property derived from Phalcon class causes segmentation fault
issues.body:
More about an issue [here](https://forum.phalconphp.com/discussion/17219/why-assigning-to-a-static-property-causes-random-segmentation-fa#C52027).

Steps to reproduce:
1. Create new project using cli.
2. Create a simple class in library folder, that extends `\Phalcon\Tag`
```php
class Tag extends \Phalcon\Tag
{
    public static function getUrlService()
    {
        self::$_escaperService = new \stdClass(); // <- this or any other assignment to any static property causes an error

        return parent::getUrlService();
    }
}
```
3. Call `Tag::getUrlService();` anywhere, in my case inside `IndexController::indexAction`.
4. Use php build-in web server and refresh page a few times.
```
╭─klatosinski@workstation ~/Code/test  
╰─➤  php -S localhost:8000 -t public                                                                                                                                                                                                                             1 ↵
PHP 7.0.22-0ubuntu0.16.04.1 Development Server started at Fri Nov  3 09:20:29 2017
Listening on http://localhost:8000
Document root is /home/klatosinski/Code/test/public
Press Ctrl-C to quit.
[Fri Nov  3 09:20:29 2017] 127.0.0.1:53566 [200]: /
zend_mm_heap corrupted
```

issues.title: [BUG] phalcon.so segfault on Centos7, PHP7.1 and latest 3.3.x branch
issues.body:
Hi,

I'm trying to run an application on Centos7, under PHP7.1 and Phalcon 3.3.x.

I'm seeing extremely unstable behaviour which results in segfaults in phalcon.so:

```
Oct 23 10:45:10 d7 kernel: php-fpm[6242]: segfault at 18 ip 00007fb5f8f31d08 sp 00007ffd8edaf9a0 error 4 in phalcon.so[7fb5f8eb3000+476000]
```

In this case crash happens very early in the app, during app modules setup. This is the class that's crashing it:

```php
abstract class ModuleTemplate implements ModuleDefinitionInterface, InjectionAwareInterface
{
....
}

issues.title: [Bug] IDE Stubs generation errors
issues.body:
_From @kornerita on August 8, 2017 13:55_

### Expected and Actual Behavior

> **Describe what you are trying to achieve and what goes wrong.**

Strings constants are not quoted and generates invalid php code.

i.e. [Zephir](https://github.com/phalcon/cphalcon/blob/master/phalcon/config.zep#L55)

Generated PHP:
```php
class Config implements \ArrayAccess, \Countable {

	const DEFAULT_PATH_DELIMITER = .;

	protected static $_pathDelimiter;
```

Expected PHP:
```php
class Config implements \ArrayAccess, \Countable {

	const DEFAULT_PATH_DELIMITER = ".";

	protected static $_pathDelimiter;

issues.title: zephir build doesn't create a dll, instead opens configure.js in Notepad++
issues.body:
I'm trying to build a dll file but it doesn't build any dll. I run this command: `zephir build`

Then the output is:
```
Preparing for PHP compilation...

issues.title: Random Core Dumps on PHP 5.5(possibly 5.6 too)
issues.body:
Some latest changes to zephir triggered somehow i think this bug in php - https://bugs.php.net/bug.php?id=64827 when running phalcon tests. I got two core dumps here:

https://pastebin.com/nMRHmf1k

Not sure what is causing it, it's not really reproducible, some times it runs fine, some times core dump and sometimes zend_mm_heap corrupted

issues.title: Extending class with static is changing null value
Access to undeclared static property
Casting resource to int
issues.body:
Hi,

Found an unexpected result when casting resources to ints (common thing in PHP):

```
    var key;
    let key =  (int) stream; //stream is resource #127
    echo $key;
```

Expected:
`127`
Current:
`1`

I always receive `1` instead of resource id. `intval` is also not working. `strval` gets `Resource id #127`

issues.title: Detect debug when building
issues.body:
I have a small idea, sometimes i forgot to write builddev when i need to, how about:

- detect if we have php compiled as debug
- if yes then `zephir build` will always build extension with debug symbols(just `zephir builddev`)
- if not then as it is
- add `zephir buildprod` so someone can build extension without debug symbols anyway

issues.title: [RFC] FastCall API
issues.body:
Currently, Zephir compiler misses a lot of cases where method caching could save some time. Some of these misses are by design (i.e., when a non-final method is called, the compiler cannot be sure which class `$this` refers to), some are compiler defects (when the same method is called in a loop).

Some of these deficiencies are dealt with by the Zephir Kernel (it tries to cache functions and methods called by the user code). However, this caching is not very efficient: a) every method/function is cached, b) cache is stored in hash tables.

FastCall API can be used to deal with these deficiencies; however, *right now* it is quite low-level and is for manual use only.

[Usage example](https://github.com/sjinks/zephir/commit/c360d861dcb2585431ae53fe9483e1f87f6600cb#diff-b913b909037a897c48b0d7f9e284dcf2R141)

[Benchmarks](https://travis-ci.org/sjinks/zephir/jobs/222133655#L4901)

PS: `fastcall` branch was branched off `master` and does not include fixes from #1509.

However, my initial impression is that it could be faster than our current CALL API.

The main question is: do we need it? :-)

@sergeyklay @Jurigag @ovr

issues.title: Better Support FreeBSD
issues.body:
I was working to get this ported to FreeBSD. There are some issues I hit that I can work around but would be nice to have addressed.
- [x] Use `#!/usr/bin/env bash` instead of `#!/bin/bash`
  - FreeBSD never installs packages to /bin, and bash is installed as a package since it is not the default shell.
- [x] Make 'bin/zepher' completely POSIX compliant to drop the dependency for **bash**
  - This might not be doable in a clean way so we may need to skip this.
- [x] Make 'parser/parser/build_linux.sh' completely POSIX compliant to drop the dependency for **bash**
- [x] Execute 'parser/parser/build_linux.sh' using /bin/sh instead of directly so this script doesn't necessarily need execute permissions.
- [ ] Replace instances of "gcc" with "cc" to drop the dependency for **gcc**
  - When I tested compiling an extension without **gcc** installed it failed because gcc was missing. I might be able to work around this by setting the CC variable to cc, but I did not have time to test this.
- [ ] Drop dependency for sudo
  - It would be nice to allow systems admins, that do not have **sudo** installed to still install extensions. I noticed when I built an extension as root, without sudo installed, the extension was silently not installed.
  - Maybe this could be accomplished with **su**? If not, we can just disregard this.

issues.title: char type does not behave as uchar with arithmetic.
issues.body:
char types should by byte values. The new arithmetic functionality however treats them as 32/64 bit ints.
example:

```zep
char ch = ' '; // space character ASCII 32
let ch += 64;
let ch += 42;
echo ch->toHex();
```

produces:
`FFFFFFFFFFFFFF8A`
instead of just `8A`.

Unreachable code false positive
Is it possible to put to rights in the manipulation with the multi-line strings?
Optimisation
Invalid new array initialisation
issues.body:
Example:

``` php
var
  variable;

let
  variable = 1;

... // any operations with variable

let
  variable = [variable];

var_dump(variable);
```

Output:

```
array(1) {
  [0]=>
  *RECURSION*
}
```

This happens because zephir generate invalid C code. 

``` c
ZEPHIR_INIT_NVAR(variable);
zephir_create_array(variable, 1, 0 TSRMLS_CC);
ZEPHIR_CHECK_POINTER(variable);
zephir_array_fast_append(variable, variable);
```

What it do:
1 Create new array and assign it to `variable`

``` php
let
  variable = [];
```

2 Add `variable` to `variable`. Add self to self.

``` php
let
  variable = [variable];
```

What he must do:
1 Create new array `tmp`

``` php
let
  tmp = [];
```

2 Add `variable` to `tmp`

``` php
let
  tmp[] = variable;
```

3 Assign `tmp` to `variable`

``` php
let
  variable = tmp;
```

4 Destroy `tmp`

``` php
unset(tmp);
```

issues.title: Undocumented inconsistencies in the handling of shortcuts.
issues.body:
In the development of my ZEP to PHP translator (https://github.com/test-to-com/zephir) I ran across an inconsistency.

Here is one example, taken from phalcon `db\rawvalue\rawvalue.zep` (line 44):

``` zephir
    /**
     * Raw value without quoting or formating
     *
     * @var string
     */
    protected _value { get, __toString };
```

This line has 2 inconsistencies:
1)  I'm aware that the Phalcon likes, like in C++, to add leading '`_`' to mark protected/private properties/methods. I have no real problem with that, since I also use and like the idea.

The problem is that, name of the getter produced even though logical, is not what I expected, from the Zephir documentation. 
This shortcut produce a  getter named getValue() and not `get_value()`!?
I didn't find anything the Zephir documentation, for shortcuts, stating that a leading '`_`' would be dropped before the `ucfirst()`!?

Worse, from the Zephir code, it seems that 2 leading '`_`' are treated differently that just '`_`':
From: `CompilerFile.php` line 318, 

``` php
            if (substr($property['name'], 0, 1) == '_') {
                $name = substr($property['name'], 1);
            } else {
                $name = $property['name'];
            }
```

this implies that if I had

``` zephir
private __value { get }; // 2 leading '_'s
```

I would get a getter with a name like `get_value()`!?

Personally, I find that, Zephir team should either:
1. Document this special case, or 
2. Generalize the handling of '`_`' to make it more useful

Example Handling:
- Drop all leading '`_`'
- use '`_`' in the middle of a property name as word breaks and then `ucfirst()` all the words

this would produce something like:
- `__default_value` (2 leading '`_`')  would produce a getter of `getDefaultValue()`, nice no :)

(which If I remember correctly, is already used in Symfony in the way it converts the routes to action function names).

This would also still maintain compatibility with the Phalcon teams coding standard.

2) Nowhere in the documentation, does it state that, '`__toString`' is also an accepted shortcut name, even though the same CompilerFile.PHP does accept that...

I personally see no benefit in accepting '`__toString`' (the leading '`__`' does not make anything more readable)...
## <bountysource-plugin>

Want to back this issue? **[Post a bounty on it!](https://www.bountysource.com/issues/27292389-undocumented-inconsistencies-in-the-handling-of-shortcuts?utm_campaign=plugin&utm_content=tracker%2F280146&utm_medium=issues&utm_source=github)** We accept bounties via [Bountysource](https://www.bountysource.com/?utm_campaign=plugin&utm_content=tracker%2F280146&utm_medium=issues&utm_source=github).
</bountysource-plugin>

issues.title: Syntax improvements
issues.body:
I have a few issues with the syntax parsing in this case. It uses it's own parser so I would expect it to be better. Expressions should just work.

I have a weird little bit of code like this:

```
                let obj->{arr["prop"]}[arr["key"]] = [
                    "a": arr["key"], "b": []
                ];
```

This fails to parse on several levels but should parse.

A secondary issue is whether or not assigning the array at that property to a variable will create a cow array or array by reference. When you need to create large structures COW arrays are extremely inefficient. I would hope the framework would provide arrays by reference by default and then a copy method for when a copy is needed. I have tested and it is COW, which is a major drawback. There is no benefit to it being COW in PHP, they just made it that way in the beginning. Importing this quirk from PHP is a major design flaw in zephir that defeats its purpose in many cases. I have worked with passing PHP arrays by pointer/reference in C extensions by hand and there is no problem with it. zvals are pointers already so it's really easy:

I don't think it is a good idea to make it too safe or managed like PHP CPP because we tested PHP CPP and half the time it gave no gains or so little gains that PHP code optimisation or using another scripting language would have done the trick. Because I can't do what I am doing in PHP in zephir my PHP code is more memory efficient by a factor of 10. zephir is useless to me until this is fixed. The point of passing around arrays in an object collection is to get around the limitations of PHP so without supporting dereferencing there PHP is faster than zephir.

At the very least I should be able to tell it that I want a pointer to the array in such and such a location rather than a copy.

var also does not support complex expressions. You need...

```
 var x;
 let x = this->something();
```

var appears to only allow literal/defalt assignment.

I cannot create a dynamic class. In PHP you can do new $classname();. I would expect new (classname)() to work but it does not.

In a switch statement I cannot declare a local variable.

issues.title: ArrayAccess incorrect behavior

It seems that classes that implement SPL ArrayAccess interface do not actually act like arrays in the Zephire code (compiled PHP classes work fine). issues.title: Cannot Call Static Methods of External Classes [$10]
issues.body:
Hello,

Zephir allows us to create objects that are not currently defined in the project like so:

``` zephir
let someObject = new \Class_From_Elsewhere();
```

However we cannot call static methods as might be expected:

``` zephir
let someResult = \Class_From_Elsewhere::someMethod("foo");
```

I'm currently using this as a workaround:

``` zephir
let someResult = call_user_func_array(
   ["\Class_From_Elsewhere", "someMethod"], ["foo"]);
```

Thank you, Zephir people!

Using Zephir at commit 416c98943db845112825eebafa5ad13acda4ce26 (Wed Apr 22).
##

issues.title: Incorrect cast to (int) and (float) for num string.
issues.body:
Example zephir:

``` php
            var
                version = "1.0 200 OK",
                floatVersion,
                intVersion;

            var_dump(version);

            let
                floatVersion = (float)version,
                intVersion   = (int)version;

            var_dump(floatVersion);
            var_dump(intVersion);
```

Output:

``` text
string(10) "1.0 200 OK"
float(0)
int(0)
```

PHP example:

``` php
$version      = "1.0 200 Found";
$intVersion   = (int)$version;
$floatVersion = (float)$version;

var_dump($version);
var_dump($intVersion);
var_dump($floatVersion);
```

Output:

``` text
string(13) "1.0 200 Found"
int(1)
double(1)
```

issues.title: Add array safe cast argument to function declarations.
issues.body:
Right now not matter what sintax we use:

``` php
public function method000(array arr){

}
```

or

``` php
public function method000(array! arr){

}
```

If we pass not array to `method000`, we get error.

``` text
PHP Catchable fatal error:  Argument 1 passed to %%%::method000() must be of the type array, %%% given in
```

Maybe add auto array safe cast in first example:

``` php
public function method000(array arr){
 var_dump(arr);
}
```

And if we pass not array to this method, zephir automatically wrap passed variable to array.
Example:

``` php
$obj->method000(1);
```

Output:

``` Text
array(1) {
  [0] =>
  int(1)
}
```

From the current documentation

> A `for` is a control structure that allows to traverse arrays or strings:

Hmm.. Frankly it's like a `foreach`. but where are `for`?!
C/C++ and PHP have `foreach` and `for`.

What about the full (conventional) support for `for`?

``` php
for ($i = 0; $i < 10; $i++) {
    echo $i;
}
```

Thanks

issues.title: Incorrect Array Built-In Method
issues.body:
How to reproduce:
### Variant with a->join(” “)

``` zephir
namespace Foo;

class Bar
{
    public function test(string! a, var b = null) ->string
    {
        if b === null || b === false {
            return a->trimleft();
        }

        if typeof b == "array" {
            let b = b->join("");
        }

        let b = preg_replace("#[-\[\]:\\\\^/]#", "\\\\$0", b);

        return preg_replace("/^[" . b . "]+/u", "", a);
    }
}
```

**Test 1:**

``` bash
php -r '$myobject = new Foo\Bar; echo $myobject->test("FOO", "F") . PHP_EOL;'
```

**Result 1:**

```
OO
```

**Test 2:**

``` bash
 php -r '$myobject = new Foo\Bar; echo $myobject->test("FOO") . PHP_EOL;'
```

**Result 2:**

```
FOO
```

**Test 3:**

``` bash
php -r '$myobject = new Foo\Bar; echo $myobject->test("ålcó", array("å", "l")) . PHP_EOL;'
```

**Result 3:**

```
Segmentation fault (core dumped)
```
### Variant with join(” “, a)

``` zephir
namespace Foo;

class Bar
{
    public function test(string! a, var b = null) ->string
    {
        if b === null || b === false {
            return a->trimleft();
        }

        if typeof b == "array" {
            let b = join("", b);
        }

        let b = preg_replace("#[-\[\]:\\\\^/]#", "\\\\$0", b);

        return preg_replace("/^[" . b . "]+/u", "", a);
    }
}
```

**Test 1:**

``` bash
php -r '$myobject = new Foo\Bar; echo $myobject->test("FOO", "F") . PHP_EOL;'
```

**Result 1:**

```
OO
```

**Test 2:**

``` bash
 php -r '$myobject = new Foo\Bar; echo $myobject->test("FOO") . PHP_EOL;'
```

**Result 2:**

```
FOO
```

**Test 3:**

``` bash
php -r '$myobject = new Foo\Bar; echo $myobject->test("ålcó", array("å", "l")) . PHP_EOL;'
```

**Result 3:**

```
có
```
### Resume
- With `a->join("")` — Segmentation fault (core dumped)
- With `join("", a)` — OK

issues.title: filter_var problem
issues.body:
php : 

``` php
$ret = "0";
var_dump(false === filter_var($ret, FILTER_VALIDATE_FLOAT, 20480));
var_dump(false == filter_var($ret, FILTER_VALIDATE_FLOAT, 20480));
var_dump(filter_var($ret, FILTER_VALIDATE_FLOAT, 20480));

php result :

boolean false
boolean true
float 0

zephir : 

``` zephir
let ret = "0";
var_dump(false === filter_var(ret, FILTER_VALIDATE_FLOAT, 20480));
var_dump(false == filter_var(ret, FILTER_VALIDATE_FLOAT, 20480));
var_dump(filter_var(ret, FILTER_VALIDATE_FLOAT, 20480));
```

zephir result :

boolean true
boolean true
float 0

issues.title: Link error, INTERNED_LEN & str_efree is not defined in PHP5.3 build on Windows
issues.body:
When building with PHP5.3 on Windows, `INTERNED_LEN` and `str_efree` is not defined, then a link error occures.

`INTERNED_LEN` & `str_efree` is in the Zend api `<Zend/zend_string.h>` which is since PHP5.4, but the Zephir kernel micros seems not quite the same as Zend api.

See:
- https://github.com/phalcon/zephir/blob/master/ext/kernel/main.h#L341
- https://github.com/phalcon/zephir/blob/master/ext/kernel/string.h#L116
- https://github.com/php/php-src/blob/PHP-5.4.34/Zend/zend_string.h
##

"traversable" type
issues.body:
Let's add "traversable" type.

``` zep
public function testSoft(traversable filter) 
{}
```

Hard:

``` zep
public function testHard(traversable! filter) 
{}
```

When "traversable" is "soft" then we will check that var has type "array" or instanced of \Traversable. If not then type have the same behavior as array.
When "traversable"  is "hard" then we will check that var has type "array" or instanced of \Traversable. If not then throws exception.

``` php
$someTraversableObj = new ArrayIterator(array());
$someNotTraversableObj = new stdClass();
$someArray = [];

$a->testSoft($someTraversableObj); // OK
$a->testSoft($someArray); // OK
$a->testSoft($someNotTraversableObj); // OK
$a->testSoft(null); // FAIL
$a->testSoft(true); // FAIL
$a->testSoft(false); // FAIL
$a->testSoft(""); // FAIL
$a->testSoft(123); // FAIL
$a->testSoft(123.5454); // FAIL
$a->testSoft($someResource); // FAIL

$a->testHard($someTraversableObj); // OK
$a->testHard($someArray); // OK
$a->testHard($someNotTraversableObj); // Exception
$a->testHard(null); // Exception
$a->testHard(true); // Exception
$a->testHard(false); // Exception
$a->testHard(123); // Exception
$a->testHard(123.5454); // Exception
$a->testHard(""); // Exception
$a->testHard($someResource); // Exception
```
##

issues.title: Private methods can't be called by owning class from parent
[NFR] Refrence parameters in __constructor
Rethinking Zephir
issues.body:
After several months working on Zephir, we are very happy with the progress so far, in a few months we will reach a beta version and then we'll enjoy all its potential. We have reached over 1000 commits and counting and there's a lot to do. This project has allowed us to do a little more CS research and it  has been very interesting for us.

Moreover, we must admit that we're not sure what will happen with PHP in the future, despite this, we are creating a tool which allows to take advantage of one the less exploited PHP features by the community at large (C extensions) and for a long time it has been reserved to experienced C programmers or advanced users. 

Also in Zephir, we have found the opportunity to implement features that we have always dreamed of PHP but for one or another reason they are not a reality today:
- [Static Typing](http://zephir-lang.com/types.html#static-types)
- [Named Parameters](http://blog.zephir-lang.com/post/76596064349/whats-new-in-zephir-v)
- [Getter/Setter shortcuts](http://zephir-lang.com/oop.html#getter-setter-shortcuts)
- [Return Type Hints](http://zephir-lang.com/oop.html#return-type-hints)
- [Throw exceptions instead of fatal errors/warnings](http://zephir-lang.com/index.html)
- [Use static types as objects](http://zephir-lang.com/builtin-methods.html)
- [And more...](http://zephir-lang.com/index.html)

We believe they will help us to build a better framework and it can help you to build your own tools in a new interesting way. Not everyone needs these features and not all may agree with them. However, we hope that one day these features will considered in the official PHP so we all can enjoy them. No matter what happens, we are sure that PHP will continue evolving regardless of the path taken.

Zephir was initially conceived as a high-level language that abstracts low-level details and allows you to compile your code. Currently based on a high-level representation it generates C code that can be compiled by leading compilers such as gcc/clang/vc with all the advantages that this brings to the table. 

Nevertheless, we know that Zephir, being a high-level language, it could also function as a meta-language rather than just a DSL (domain specific language).

After thinking a bit on this I'm creating this thread to discuss an idea with you guys. 

If we could restructure Zephir so that it can generate code in both PHP and C, this could make Zephir a much more powerful tool than ever before.

Generating C:
- The code can be compiled, improving performance and reducing resource consumption
- Some important level of code protection
- Code is exported as a C-extension (shared library or Windows DLL)

``` bash
zephir generate c
```

Generating PHP:
- PHP code can run everywhere where the language is available (shared hostings, servers with restrictions, other PHP implementations, etc)
- Code is exported as a PHP library (phar, standard PHP library installable via composer, etc)

``` bash
zephir generate php
```

Using C-extensions:
- Production environments, when more performance is required and install c-extensions is feasible

Using PHP libraries:
- Development/Testing environments, other restricted environments, other PHP implementations, etc.

Possible cons: 
- C code blocks cannot be exported to PHP 
- Integrations with low level C libraries couldn't be exported to PHP
- Introduce incompatibilities due to the different runtimes (can be solved with enough tests)

With regard to this we can: 

a) Implement this now 
b) Release Zephir 1.0 (aka stable) and implement this after that
c) Do not implement it at all

Looking forward to your comments,

commit.message: Code cleanup, removed no longer used variables

ZE3: Fixed adding reference counter for scalar values

PHP doesn't allocate scalar values in heap but do it directly on VM
stack, inside HashTables and object. They are not subjects for
reference counting and garbage collection anymore. Scalar values
don't have reference counter and don't support Z_ADDREF*(), Z_DELREF*(),
Z_REFCOUNT*() and Z_SET_REFCOUNT*() macros anymore. In most cases we
should check if zval supports these macros before calling them.
Otherwise we'll get an assert() or crash.
Minor fixes for SymbolTable (CS, comparing objects, PHPDoc)

Hi there,

Thanks for the feedback and questions.

What the ./install script is doing with my mod is to simply install zephir in /usr/local/bin, which should be in your path. the /usr/local/bin/zephir script knows where to find zephir, no need for environment variables.
Therefore, you can just type commands as such:

cd /where/ever
zephir init myext
cd /where/ever/myext
<write code here>
zephir generate
zephir compile
zephir install

With all your code in /where/ever/myext, the extension will be built into /where/ever/myext/ext.
Good idea using basename(getcwd()) as default namespace.

Decoupling zephir itself from the extension you're building is much easier - try building a new extension as it stands, it's hard :-)

@mobli Just like npm / composer do, NOT everybody happy to install it to /usr/local/bin.

So with origin zephir shell script it will auto detect ZEPHIRDIR enviroment is set? 
If set , using user's ZEPHIRDIR (Like yours).
If not set, using the current shell script's parent path.

It's behavior like yours, but more flexible. right?

And you are welcome.

It doesn't really matter to me how it's done, as long as I can decouple zephir from the work I'm doing now.
So for instance, I might install zephir in /opt but work in ~/projects. I don't want to have to change my .profile file every time I add a new tool, which is what I need to do to make ZEPHIRDIR sticky.
I can the mods as you requested so as not to install zephir in /usr/local/bin because I really need that pull request to go through, but I'd prefer if you could reconsider your position on that. Please let me know ;-)

I can't still understand this proposed structure, Phalcon 2.0 is not compiling due to this, what are the advantages of this structure?
I'm restoring the old behavior

It works like a charm in fact:

1) Install Zephir:

```
cd /opt
git clone https://github.com/phalcon/zephir.git
cd zephir
./install -c
```

2) Create a new project:

```
cd /projects
zephir init newproject
cd newproject
```

or

```
cd /projects
mkdir newproject
cd newproject
zephir init
```

`config.json` is created in `/projects/newproject`.
Write your code in `/projects/newproject` and subdirectories.
Then, in `/projects/newproject`:

```
zephir <generate|compile|install>
```

A new directory is created `/projects/newproject/ext`. The new extension is built in there and installed if required.

It's closer to how the `ext_skel` utility works from PHP than to composer and it's much more comfortable this way. Also, note how the test included with Zephir is self contained: it doesn't pollute the ext directory anymore.

If you install zephir the normal way using ./install then you will have to set the ZEPHIRDIR as before.

I like the idea, however, this would sometimes make things harder for the compiler, because there could be unregistered activity the language cannot track, for instance:

``` c
 %{
a = fibonacci(MAX_FACTOR);
}%
```

The variable 'a' is mutated inside a "shadow" block of code, for Zephir, the variable wasn't mutated so the variable will be reported as unused, but the variable was actually used!

Our idea of integrate C-functions into Zephir is via optimizers. Check this example: 

https://github.com/phalcon/zephir/blob/master/Library/Optimizers/FunctionCall/StrlenOptimizer.php#L25

It intercepts calls to 'strlen' and replaces the generated code by a call to a c-function. 

It also adds the proper header: 
https://github.com/phalcon/zephir/blob/master/Library/Optimizers/FunctionCall/StrlenOptimizer.php#L43

Returns a 'compiled expression' which has the right data-type Zephir can understand.
https://github.com/phalcon/zephir/blob/master/Library/Optimizers/FunctionCall/StrlenOptimizer.php#L46

@phalcon I agree.

In the most case, Zephir user should use Optimized Function Calls we provided.
And we will implementing populate and general function calls to Optimized c-function.

Zephir is a DSL and Generate to c . 
So i think it should have an ability to calling 3rd c libraries.
It will make Zephir more flexible and powerful.

For instance
1. Declare the interfaces for c libraries - like `VALA` .
2. Embedded codeblock to generated target files. like `XPIDL`, `CoffeeScript`.
-  CoffeeScript Embedded Javascript - http://coffeescript.org/#embedded
  And just like CoffeeScript Document says:

> Hopefully, you'll never need to use it, but if you ever need to intersperse snippets of JavaScript within your CoffeeScript, you can use backticks to pass it straight through. 

Go back to my example `cblock.zep` https://github.com/racklin/zephir/blob/d6b1e3651151c0e1c66cd58ff024be967b190ab0/test/cblock.zep
`fibonacci(40)` is very slow in PHP - benchmark [http://fengmk2.github.io/blog/2011/fibonacci/nodejs-python-php-ruby-lua.html]

But Zephir with CBLOCK, we can implement simple c-function `fibonacci` in zephir CBLOCK. and calling in zephir . NOW with Zephir extension, `fibonacii(40)` only used _0.8s_ in my MBP.

And the other example is Zephir currently not support `require` php file.
With cblock , we can `#include "kernel/require.h"` and calling `zephir_require` or `zephir_require_ret` in cblock.

So, with Optimizer FunctionCall + CBLOCK will make Zephir more flexible and these two features were complementary not mutex .  

Finally, You CAN calling c-function, implements c-function in `CBLOCK`, not mean You SHOULD.
:smile:

@phalcon I agree and understand your concerns.

Please consider that CBLOCK or (c-code with comments) is part of Zephir features, It make Zephir flexible.

The most projects(and Phalcon 2.0) developers SHOULD NOT using CBLOCK to implements or calling c-function.
But sometimes or special extensions,they CAN use CBLOCK and that is helpful.

As list before, `XPIDL` , `CoffeeScript` support embedded target code modifiers.

Google's `Go`  (http://golang.org/) also have a c-code embedded by comments, called 
c-go . (http://golang.org/cmd/cgo/) .

Don't get my wrong, I'm going to continue to work with Zephir, I'm not wanting to convey a message of "Zephir is slow" that's not the case.

It did give me an extremely interesting idea however. (it's pretty far outside the box) What if, the calls to internal PHP functions (at least the simple ones, like trim(), explode(), etc) used the actual PHP internals call for the specified function instead of the zephir_call_func_p\* methods?

Nearly all the PHP source is documented with method calls and their signatures, so what if there was a way to do some type of reflection, or 'read' the code's documentation? 

For example, the explode function has the following signature:
proto array explode(string separator, string str [, int limit])

having that signature, and knowing that the internal functions are named php_<function name>, you could deduce that you can call php_explode(zval *delim, zval *str, zval *return_value, long limit)

I imagine I could also just use the cblock abilities to call php_explode myself however.

$parameter['mandatory']  like 0 1 in you clouse

``` php
$codePrinter->output("\t" . 'ZEND_ARG_ARRAY_INFO(0, ' . $parameter['name'] . ', ' . $parameter['mandatory'] . 
```

What is "clouse"?

$parameter['mandatory'] has a different meaning, $parameter['default'] is what we need there.

if statement*
Okey, but what does it mean mandatory?

$parameter['mandatory'] only applies to the parameter's type, it means you have to pass the exact type, generated code by Zephir will not perform any extra conversions if a different type is passed. Presence of $parameter['default'] means the parameter is optional.

Basically removing that line in either version would not add characters, which are
determined to be lowercase. That would give you incomplete results in most cases.

To fix that one would need to detect if a character is uppercase and handle it similar to a
delimiter 

even though that's a bit tricky, if you have something like `testAB`
where you might want `testAb` insteadof `testAB`

When I use something called `(un) camelize` I expect that the string will be _(un) camelized_. I do not expect that this function will change the case of arbitrary characters. Because function called `camelize`, not `camelize_and_normalize`, `camelize_and_upper(lower)_case`, etc.
then the fix would easily be to just use `ch` insteadof `tolower(ch)`, do you think that would work?

Yeah

P.S. Just found https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CamelCase

Actually I believe that the design of both functions is disgusting because it is easy to pick up such cases when the inverse transform is incompatible. For example `camelize(uncamelize(camelize("_Test")))`

is there any reason you removed this line?

Just because you saw no impact it doesn't mean there won't be one.
Removing that would be ok if there was no 7.X version using it.

Even your own code example shows why it's not a good idea:
`ZEND_ASSERT(fci->symbol_table == NULL);` might fail since `->symbol_table`
might be initialized to a not-null value (due to not-zeroed memory allocation).

So we'll have to wrap this into ifdef's for 7.1.X. 
(since that won't land in PHP7.0.X exactly for that backwards-compatibility argument above)

If you follow the execution path after the line :

fci.symbol_table = null in zephir_call_user_function

the unique usage of fci->symbol_table is in extended/fcall.c, line 144.

we never go into the code of PHP in this context, so why initialize an
attribut when it's not used.

So I'm agree I can add a :

#if PHP_VERSION_ID < 70100
  ...
#endif

to be more secure.

review_comments.body:
I mean something like (not sure about macros name)

```c
#define CREATE_OBJECT_OR_ADD_REF(zval_ptr) \
    if (Z_TYPE_P(zval_ptr) != IS_OBJECT) { \
        zval *arg = object; \
        ALLOC_INIT_ZVAL(object); \
        object_init_ex(object, zend_exception_get_default(TSRMLS_C)); \
        ZEPHIR_CALL_METHOD(NULL, object, "__construct", NULL, 0, arg); \
    } else { \
        Z_ADDREF_P(zval_ptr); \
    }
```

This gathers all used variables (the code is from https://github.com/phalcon/zephir/blob/master/Library/ClassMethod.php#L1999), then retrieves only those which are initialized with `zval_used_for_init` (https://github.com/phalcon/zephir/blob/master/Library/Backends/ZendEngine2/Backend.php#L268).
The only issue is that this is ZE2-specific method :-(
This is specific only to this method
Well, never mind then 👍

@sjinks I'm pretty sure that it doesn't resolve the issue for the PHP 7.0 (ZE3) because it is ZE2. Also it seems this may cause performance regression for PHP 5.6.

@sjinks Just inspected this in ZE2 and ZE3.

**ZE2** (before `zend_call_function`):
```
print fcic.called_scope.name.val   # (zend_class_entry *) 0x0
print fcic.calling_scope.name.val  # (zend_class_entry *) 0x0
print fcic.object_ptr              # (zval *) 0x0
print print fcic.function_handler  # (zend_function *) 0x0
```

**ZE3** (before `zend_call_function`):
```
printf "%s\n", fcic.called_scope.name.val                     # Group\PrivateCaller
printf "%s\n", fcic.calling_scope.name.val                    # Group\PrivateCaller
printf "%s\n", fcic.object.ce.name.val                        # Group\PrivateCaller
printf "%s\n", fcic.function_handler.common.function_name.val # runBar
```

Actually I like your solution with `populate_fcic` and `resolve_callable` for ZE3. Could you please try to backport they to the ZE2?
